awd_titl_txt: Liger: Initiating Fabrication of Next Generation Keck Imager and Spectrograph
awd_abstract_narration:
The Liger instrument will allow astronomers to study solar systems around other stars, other galaxies and the regions near black holes.   This instrument is a large complex unit.  This project will allow the team developing this concept to continue their design work and build an important component of that system that operates at low temperature. In addition, the participants plan to expand a portable planetarium outreach program, Cosmic Tours, to better support San Diego County elementary and middle schools with curated shows that incorporate the Next Generation Science Standards.

The Liger instrument envisaged for deployment at the Keck Observatory will combine an adaptive optics-fed integral field spectrograph and imaging camera that operate simultaneously in the near-infrared (0.81-2.45 μm). This project will maintain Liger’s fabrication momentum and provide the necessary research and development on a subsystem of the full instrument. Specifically, the plan is to fabricate, integrate, and cryogenically characterize the imager detector assembly that houses both the Teleydne Hawaii-2RG detector and pick-off mirrors that direct light to each of the lenslet and slicer integral field spectrograph components. A cryogenic chamber will be fabricated and integrated for alignment of the Liger imager and for testing the detector assembly. In parallel, software will be developed that uses the latest MACIE controllers with the Teledyne Hawaii-2RG. This testing will be the main component of a graduate student’s thesis work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Developing new astronomical instruments is essential for making groundbreaking discoveries about our universe and understanding Earth's place in it. Technological advancements directly contribute to these discoveries. Large telescopes on Earth offer opportunities to innovate with new cameras and spectrographs to study the cosmos more effectively.

Our team has designed a unique, state-of-the-art instrument named Liger. This instrument operates at near-infrared wavelengths and functions in a cryogenic, vacuum environment, cooled to -200°C. The Liger instrument combines a near-infrared imaging camera with a sophisticated spectrograph that disperses incoming light into thousands of individual spectra (similar to rainbows). The instrument's mechanical assembly is specially designed to support both the detector and mirrors, which direct the light into two separate spectrographs.

This NSF grant was over one year and supported the design, fabrication, and integration of the near-infrared detector, which uses a specialized format to capture light and feed it into a unique portion of the spectrograph. The grant also funded software development to readout and process data from the detector.

Our team successfully completed the design, fabrication, and integration of the detector into the mechanical assembly that includes the unique small adjacent mirrors and cryogenic focusing mechanisms. The software and electronics of the detector assembly has been integrated and testing of reading detector is being advanced. 

The awarded program included a broader impacts component of providing planetarium shows to K-8 public schools in San Diego County. Personnel from this program designed a planetarium curriculum aligned with the California state astronomy standards. We incorporated Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) into our planetarium presentations. For K-2 students, we followed the standards for Grade 1, which focus on making observations of the sky and predicting patterns. Since the planetarium has the ability to "speed up time," phenomena like the phases of the moon can be demonstrated quickly. Another important part of the standard is understanding that stars are "present" during the daytime but are blocked by the glare of the Sun—something that can also be easily demonstrated in the planetarium. For Grades 3-5, we followed standards that focus on graphical representations of observable phenomena, such as the seasonal patterns of stars. Our planetarium shows highlighted the constellations visible at different times of the year, and we used time-lapse techniques to show how constellations change over time. For middle school students, we started with elementary-level concepts of the night sky and then expanded the content to include immersive videos that project the geometry of the Sun-Earth-Moon system onto the planetarium dome. We designed specific modules tailored to each grade level and visited over a dozen schools during this period. This planetarium program, called Cosmic Tours, is still in monthly operation in San Diego County.

Once completed, the Liger instrument will be installed at the W.M. Keck Observatory, contributing to a broad range of scientific investigations. These include studying objects in our Solar System, the Milky Way, extrasolar planets, black holes, distant galaxies, and stars—helping to deepen our understanding of the cosmos.
